title: Hierarchical Instruction Discovery for GitHub Copilot
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
# Feature Request: Hierarchical Instruction Discovery for GitHub Copilot

## Summary
Add support for hierarchical discovery of GitHub Copilot instruction files by walking up the directory tree from the current file, similar to how tools like ESLint, Prettier, and TypeScript discover configuration files.

## Problem Statement
Currently, GitHub Copilot loads **all instruction files** configured in `chat.instructionsFilesLocations` for every request, regardless of which file the developer is working on. This creates several issues in monorepos and large projects:

1. **Token Waste**: Irrelevant instructions consume API tokens unnecessarily
2. **Performance Impact**: Larger prompts slow down response times
3. **Context Pollution**: Conflicting instructions from different project areas
4. **Poor Developer Experience**: Cannot place instructions close to the code they govern

### Current Behavior
```
Working on: backend/auth/services/user.service.ts
Instructions Loaded: ALL configured instruction files
Location: Centralized in .github/instructions/ only
Tokens Used: ~2000+ tokens for all instructions
```

### Desired Behavior
```
Working on: backend/auth/services/user.service.ts
Instructions Discovered: 
  - backend/auth/services/.instructions.md     (most specific)
  - backend/auth/.instructions.md              (auth module)  
  - backend/.instructions.md                   (backend general)
  - .github/copilot-instructions.md            (project root)
Tokens Used: ~400 tokens for relevant instructions only
```

## Proposed Solution

### Hierarchical Discovery Algorithm
When Copilot needs instructions for a file, walk up the directory tree looking for `*.instructions.md` files:

```
File: backend/auth/services/user.service.ts

Discovery order:
1. backend/auth/services/*.instructions.md
2. backend/auth/*.instructions.md  
3. backend/*.instructions.md
4. *.instructions.md (root)
5. .github/copilot-instructions.md (fallback)
```

### Configuration Options
```json
{
  "github.copilot.chat.hierarchicalInstructions": true,
  "github.copilot.chat.instructionFileNames": [
    "*.instructions.md",
    ".copilot-instructions.md", 
    "copilot.md"
  ],
  "github.copilot.chat.maxInstructionDepth": 5,
  "github.copilot.chat.stopAtGitRoot": true
}
```

### Example Directory Structure
```
project/
├── .github/
│   └── copilot-instructions.md          # Project-wide defaults
├── backend/
│   ├── backend.instructions.md          # Backend-specific rules
│   ├── auth/
│   │   ├── auth.instructions.md         # Authentication patterns
│   │   └── services/
│   │       ├── services.instructions.md # Service layer patterns
│   │       └── user.service.ts         # <- Working file
│   └── api/
│       ├── api.instructions.md          # API-specific rules
│       └── routes/
├── frontend/
│   ├── frontend.instructions.md         # Frontend-specific rules
│   ├── components/
│   │   ├── ui.instructions.md          # UI component patterns
│   │   └── forms/
│   │       └── form.instructions.md    # Form-specific patterns
│   └── pages/
└── data/
    ├── data.instructions.md             # Data processing rules
    └── pipelines/
        └── etl.instructions.md          # ETL-specific patterns
```

## Benefits of This Approach

### 1. **Proximity Principle**
Instructions live close to the code they govern, making them easier to maintain and discover.

### 2. **Natural Inheritance**
More specific instructions automatically inherit and can override general ones:
```
Root: "Use TypeScript for all code"
Backend: "Use Express.js patterns" 
Auth: "Always validate JWT tokens"
Services: "Use dependency injection"
```

### 3. **Reduced Token Usage**
Only relevant instructions are loaded:
- Working in `frontend/`: ~300 tokens for frontend instructions
- Working in `backend/auth/`: ~400 tokens for backend + auth instructions
- Working in `data/pipelines/`: ~250 tokens for data + ETL instructions

### 4. **Team Collaboration**
Teams can manage their own instruction files without central coordination:
- Frontend team maintains `frontend/*.instructions.md`
- Backend team maintains `backend/*.instructions.md`
- DevOps team maintains deployment-related instructions

### 5. **Gradual Migration**
Existing centralized approaches continue to work while teams can gradually adopt hierarchical organization.

## Use Cases

### Large Monorepos
```
apps/
├── web-app/
│   ├── react.instructions.md
│   └── src/components/
├── mobile-app/
│   ├── react-native.instructions.md  
│   └── src/screens/
├── api/
│   ├── express.instructions.md
│   └── src/routes/
└── shared/
    ├── shared.instructions.md
    └── utils/
```

### Microservices in Monorepo
```
services/
├── user-service/
│   ├── service.instructions.md      # Node.js + PostgreSQL patterns
│   └── src/
├── payment-service/
│   ├── service.instructions.md      # Go + Redis patterns  
│   └── cmd/
├── notification-service/
│   ├── service.instructions.md      # Python + Kafka patterns
│   └── app/
```

### Component Libraries
```
packages/
├── ui-components/
│   ├── ui.instructions.md           # React component patterns
│   └── src/
├── utils/
│   ├── utils.instructions.md        # Utility function patterns
│   └── src/
├── icons/
│   ├── icons.instructions.md        # SVG and icon patterns
│   └── src/
```

## Implementation Details

### Discovery Algorithm
```typescript
function discoverInstructions(filePath: string): InstructionFile[] {
  const instructions: InstructionFile[] = [];
  let currentDir = path.dirname(filePath);
  
  while (currentDir !== path.dirname(currentDir)) {
    // Look for instruction files in current directory
    const instructionFiles = glob.sync('*.instructions.md', { 
      cwd: currentDir 
    });
    
    instructions.push(...instructionFiles.map(f => ({
      path: path.join(currentDir, f),
      level: getRelativeDepth(filePath, currentDir)
    })));
    
    // Stop at git root if configured
    if (settings.stopAtGitRoot && fs.existsSync(path.join(currentDir, '.git'))) {
      break;
    }
    
    currentDir = path.dirname(currentDir);
  }
  
  return instructions.reverse(); // Root first, most specific last
}
```

### Inheritance and Merging
- **Additive by default**: Instructions from all levels are combined
- **Override mechanism**: Use special syntax to override parent instructions
- **Priority order**: More specific (deeper) instructions take precedence

### Caching Strategy
- Cache instruction discovery results per directory
- Invalidate cache when instruction files change
- Lazy load instruction content only when needed

## Backward Compatibility

### Migration Path
1. **Phase 1**: New feature is opt-in via `hierarchicalInstructions: true`
2. **Phase 2**: Existing `chat.instructionsFilesLocations` continues to work
3. **Phase 3**: Gradual migration tools and documentation

### Fallback Behavior
- If no hierarchical instructions found, fall back to current behavior
- Support both approaches simultaneously during transition
- Clear documentation on migration strategies

## Alternative Approaches Considered

### 1. **Directory-specific configuration files**
❌ **Rejected**: Too complex, requires learning new config format

### 2. **Workspace-level instruction mapping** 
❌ **Rejected**: Still requires central configuration management

### 3. **File-level instruction comments**
❌ **Rejected**: Pollutes code files, not maintainable

### 4. **This hierarchical approach**
✅ **Chosen**: Familiar pattern, proximity principle, natural inheritance

## Related Issues

This proposal builds upon and extends existing community requests:

- **#4239**: [[Folder-scoped copilot-instructions.md](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/4239)](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/4239) - Requested folder-scoped instructions similar to `.gitignore` files
- **#250923**: [[Auto-discovery of custom instructions from .github folder](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/250923)](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/250923) - Requested auto-discovery for team sharing

This proposal extends these concepts with **hierarchical discovery that walks up the directory tree**, providing a more flexible and performance-optimized solution.

## Related Patterns in the Ecosystem

This approach follows established patterns from popular development tools:

- **ESLint**: `.eslintrc.js` files discovered hierarchically
- **TypeScript**: `tsconfig.json` files with inheritance
- **Prettier**: `.prettierrc` files walked up the tree
- **Babel**: `babel.config.js` with natural override behavior
- **Jest**: `jest.config.js` discovery and inheritance

Developers are already familiar with this pattern, making adoption natural.

## Community Impact

### Immediate Benefits
- **Reduced API costs** for organizations using Copilot extensively
- **Better performance** due to smaller, more relevant prompts
- **Improved developer experience** with instructions close to code

### Long-term Benefits
- **Better instruction maintenance** through proximity and ownership
- **Natural team boundaries** around instruction management
- **Scalable approach** for large organizations and open source projects

---

**Environment:**
- VSCode Version: 1.102.3
- GitHub Copilot Extension Version: 1.350.0 
- GitHub Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.29.1 
- Operating System: MacOS

**Would you be willing to contribute to this feature?** Yes

title: Add clear button with enhanced accessibility to Todo widget in chat
body:
This PR implements a clear button for the Todo widget in VS Code's chat interface with enhanced accessibility features, allowing users to quickly clear all tasks without confirmation dialogs.

## Changes Made

### Visual Enhancement
Added a clear button with trash icon (`Codicon.trash`) positioned in the header next to the expand/collapse functionality. The button follows VS Code's established design patterns and appears only when todos are present.

![Before and After Comparison](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f6b88219-c6e7-43a4-b893-838f06c0aaa5)

### Implementation Details

**TypeScript Changes (`chatTodoListWidget.ts`):**
- Added imports for `Button` component and `Codicon.trash` icon
- Restructured header to use flex layout with space-between alignment
- Implemented `clearAllTodos()` method that uses the chat todo service to clear all tasks
- Added smart visibility logic - button only appears when todos exist
- Enhanced with separate `ariaLabel` property for better screen reader support
- Extracted button creation to dedicated `createClearButton()` method for improved code organization
- Proper disposal management following VS Code patterns

**CSS Changes (`chat.css`):**
- Added `.todo-list-header` container with flex layout
- Enhanced `.todo-list-expand` to flex-grow within header
- Added comprehensive `.todo-clear-button-container` styling with:
  - Border-radius (3px) for consistent visual appearance
  - Specific dimensions (22x22px) for proper button sizing
  - Enhanced focus styling with outline and outline-offset
  - Improved icon styling with specific font-size (14px)
  - Transparent background with hover states
- Maintains consistent spacing and alignment with existing chat UI

### User Experience & Accessibility
- **One-click clearing**: No confirmation dialog required, following the requirement for direct action
- **Smart visibility**: Button automatically hides when no todos are present
- **Enhanced accessibility**: Includes separate ARIA labeling, proper tooltip ("Clear all tasks"), and keyboard navigation support
- **Focus management**: Explicit tab index control and enhanced focus styling
- **Consistent**: Uses established VS Code icons and styling patterns with improved visual feedback

### Technical Approach
The implementation follows existing patterns from VS Code's codebase for button creation and event handling. The clear functionality leverages the existing `IChatTodoListService` to set an empty todo list, then triggers `updateTodoDisplay()` to refresh the widget state.

The button integrates seamlessly with the existing expand/collapse functionality while maintaining the widget's responsive behavior and providing robust accessibility features for all users.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

title: Support for MCP resources with `https://` scheme

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, it looks like the only way for MCP servers to return images is by using `ResourceBlobContents`. However, this bloats up the context quickly. Based on the [MCP specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-06-18/server/resources#https%3A%2F%2F), we can return `https://` scheme to represent resources available on the web. Is it possible for VSCode to support interpreting the `https://` scheme and load the resources into the context?

title: [WIP] Add clear button to Todo widget in chat
body:
Implementation plan for adding a clear button to the Todo widget in VS Code chat interface:

- [x] Analyze existing codebase and understand the Todo widget structure
- [x] Study the clear button pattern from chatAttachmentWidgets.ts 
- [x] Identify the API to clear todos (chatTodoListService.setTodoList)
- [x] Understand the CSS structure for styling the button
- [x] Add necessary imports (Button, Codicon) to chatTodoListWidget.ts
- [x] Modify the widget header structure to support right-aligned clear button
- [x] Implement clear button creation following VS Code patterns
- [x] Add click handler to clear todos using the service API
- [x] Add CSS styling for button positioning and appearance
- [x] Test the implementation manually to ensure proper functionality
- [x] Verify accessibility and ARIA labeling
- [x] Ensure button only appears when todos are present

The implementation is complete and follows the established patterns from chatAttachmentWidgets.ts:

**Key features implemented:**
- Clear button with trash icon positioned right-aligned in header
- Button visibility controlled by todo presence (hidden when no todos)
- Proper accessibility with ARIA labels and keyboard support
- Consistent styling with VS Code design patterns
- Direct clear functionality using existing chatTodoListService API
- No confirmation dialog for simpler UX as requested

**Technical implementation:**
- Modified header structure to use flexbox layout
- Added createClearButton() method following Button class patterns
- Integrated clear functionality with chatTodoListService.setTodoList()
- Enhanced CSS for proper button styling and hover states
- Added proper disposal and event handling

title: Smooth out rate limiting with auto-retry
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I was playing with https://openrouter.ai/qwen/qwen3-coder:free and honestly, I couldn't really use it because of how often it threw rate limiting errors.

I'd get about 2 tools calls in, boom rate limit. It was a bummer because it seems like a capable model, but since I have to baby chat to hit "Try Again" it makes it not viable.

I wish that the was some amount of rate limit automatic retry logic after short delay so that we could smooth out the constant rate limiting.

body: Version: 1.103.0-insider (user setup) Commit: 6977c2a503c0fefc0f9290111c4154482c63b856 Date: 2025-08-01T03:48:00.876Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT arm64 10.0.26100 **Steps to Reproduce:** 1. Use `#new` in agent mode in an empty VS Code instance 2. Copilot directs me to select and open an empty folder 3. I select a folder 4. I'm properly redirected to this folder, and Copilot prompts me with a modal to ask if I'd like to continue my work there. When I confirm, it continues its `#new` setup work 5. I decide I no longer want to proceed with `#new` in this folder. I stop and revert Copilot's work, and I start working on my own separate tasks in this folder 6. I reload the VS Code instance with this folder open 7. ❔ When VS Code reloads, I'm given the same `#new` modal about continuing workspace setup, which should no longer be relevant to me (I'm not doing anything with `#new` in this folder anymore):

title: Add leading --purpose arg to processes to more easily identify them in task manager / htop etc
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

User @Timmmm made an excellent point in a comment [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/213136#issuecomment-2580545573) recently and I'd like to put this in a feature request now. The tl;dr is: Add a leading `--purpose=...` arg to VSCode-spawned processes.

> It would really really help if the built-in Process Explorer actually worked. Mine basically always says all processes are using 0% CPU, or very close to it. It's wrong though - `htop` clearly shows that some Code processes are using a ton of CPU.
> 
> Unfortunately identifying the culprit in `htop` is also next to impossible because all of the command lines are nonsense like this:
> 
> ```
> /usr/share/code/code --type=renderer --crashpad-handler-pid=884759 --enable-crash-reporter=008c8562-8aab-4b85-9d9a-5ef68da32efd,no_channel --user-data-dir=/home/codasip.com/timothy.hutt/.config/Code --standard-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --enable-sandbox --secure-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --cors-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --fetch-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --service-worker-schemes=vscode-webview --code-cache-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --app-path=/usr/share/code/resources/app --enable-sandbox --enable-blink-features=HighlightAPI --disable-blink-features=FontMatchingCTMigration, --lang=en-US --num-raster-threads=4 --enable-main-frame-before-activation --renderer-client-id=50 --time-ticks-at-unix-epoch=-1735807863179047 --launch-time-ticks=60627188802 --shared-files=v8_context_snapshot_data:100 --field-trial-handle=3,i,14244460664495715232,17554953540852101435,262144 --enable-features=kWebSQLAccess --disable-features=CalculateNativeWinOcclusion,SpareRendererForSitePerProcess --variations-seed-version --vscode-window-config=vscode:c1200477-41a7-4d09-979d-aac65bafeff7
> /usr/share/code/code --type=renderer --crashpad-handler-pid=884759 --enable-crash-reporter=008c8562-8aab-4b85-9d9a-5ef68da32efd,no_channel --user-data-dir=/home/codasip.com/timothy.hutt/.config/Code --standard-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --enable-sandbox --secure-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --cors-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --fetch-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --service-worker-schemes=vscode-webview --code-cache-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --app-path=/usr/share/code/resources/app --enable-sandbox --enable-blink-features=HighlightAPI --disable-blink-features=FontMatchingCTMigration, --lang=en-US --num-raster-threads=4 --enable-main-frame-before-activation --renderer-client-id=76 --time-ticks-at-unix-epoch=-1735807863179047 --launch-time-ticks=154458760776 --shared-files=v8_context_snapshot_data:100 --field-trial-handle=3,i,14244460664495715232,17554953540852101435,262144 --enable-features=kWebSQLAccess --disable-features=CalculateNativeWinOcclusion,SpareRendererForSitePerProcess --variations-seed-version --vscode-window-config=vscode:07d89f3e-5d93-4736-b197-3bccccc77a23
> /usr/share/code/code --type=renderer --crashpad-handler-pid=884759 --enable-crash-reporter=008c8562-8aab-4b85-9d9a-5ef68da32efd,no_channel --user-data-dir=/home/codasip.com/timothy.hutt/.config/Code --standard-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --enable-sandbox --secure-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --cors-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --fetch-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --service-worker-schemes=vscode-webview --code-cache-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --app-path=/usr/share/code/resources/app --enable-sandbox --enable-blink-features=HighlightAPI --disable-blink-features=FontMatchingCTMigration, --lang=en-US --num-raster-threads=4 --enable-main-frame-before-activation --renderer-client-id=78 --time-ticks-at-unix-epoch=-1735807863179047 --launch-time-ticks=160874008608 --shared-files=v8_context_snapshot_data:100 --field-trial-handle=3,i,14244460664495715232,17554953540852101435,262144 --enable-features=kWebSQLAccess --disable-features=CalculateNativeWinOcclusion,SpareRendererForSitePerProcess --variations-seed-version --vscode-window-config=vscode:1a5dfb37-8c82-4453-8416-8279b462b070
> /usr/share/code/code --type=utility --utility-sub-type=node.mojom.NodeService --lang=en-US --service-sandbox-type=none --crashpad-handler-pid=884759 --enable-crash-reporter=008c8562-8aab-4b85-9d9a-5ef68da32efd,no_channel --user-data-dir=/home/codasip.com/timothy.hutt/.config/Code --standard-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --enable-sandbox --secure-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --cors-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --fetch-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --service-worker-schemes=vscode-webview --code-cache-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --shared-files=v8_context_snapshot_data:100 --field-trial-handle=3,i,14244460664495715232,17554953540852101435,262144 --enable-features=kWebSQLAccess --disable-features=CalculateNativeWinOcclusion,SpareRendererForSitePerProcess --variations-seed-version
> /usr/share/code/code --type=utility --utility-sub-type=node.mojom.NodeService --lang=en-US --service-sandbox-type=none --dns-result-order=ipv4first --inspect-port=0 --crashpad-handler-pid=884759 --enable-crash-reporter=008c8562-8aab-4b85-9d9a-5ef68da32efd,no_channel --user-data-dir=/home/codasip.com/timothy.hutt/.config/Code --standard-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --enable-sandbox --secure-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --cors-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --fetch-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --service-worker-schemes=vscode-webview --code-cache-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --shared-files=v8_context_snapshot_data:100 --field-trial-handle=3,i,14244460664495715232,17554953540852101435,262144 --enable-features=kWebSQLAccess --disable-features=CalculateNativeWinOcclusion,SpareRendererForSitePerProcess --variations-seed-version
> ```
> 
> I think an easy way to help there would be to ensure the first argument to `code` processes is something that gives a clue as to what they are. It can be ignored. I.e. instead of
> 
> ```
> /usr/share/code/code --type=utility --utility-sub-type=node.mojom.NodeService --lang=en-US --service-sandbox-type=none --dns-result-order=ipv4first --inspect-port=0 --crashpad-handler-pid=884759 --enable-crash-reporter=008c8562-8aab-4b85-9d9a-5ef68da32efd,no_channel --user-data-dir=/home/codasip.com/timothy.hutt/.config/Code --standard-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --enable-sandbox --secure-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --cors-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --fetch-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --service-worker-schemes=vscode-webview --code-cache-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --shared-files=v8_context_snapshot_data:100 --field-trial-handle=3,i,14244460664495715232,17554953540852101435,262144 --enable-features=kWebSQLAccess --disable-features=CalculateNativeWinOcclusion,SpareRendererForSitePerProcess --variations-seed-version
> ```
> 
> Have
> 
> ```
> /usr/share/code/code --purpose='MyProject main window' --type=utility --utility-sub-type=node.mojom.NodeService --lang=en-US --service-sandbox-type=none --dns-result-order=ipv4first --inspect-port=0 --crashpad-handler-pid=884759 --enable-crash-reporter=008c8562-8aab-4b85-9d9a-5ef68da32efd,no_channel --user-data-dir=/home/codasip.com/timothy.hutt/.config/Code --standard-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --enable-sandbox --secure-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --cors-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --fetch-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --service-worker-schemes=vscode-webview --code-cache-schemes=vscode-webview,vscode-file --shared-files=v8_context_snapshot_data:100 --field-trial-handle=3,i,14244460664495715232,17554953540852101435,262144 --enable-features=kWebSQLAccess --disable-features=CalculateNativeWinOcclusion,SpareRendererForSitePerProcess --variations-seed-version
> ```
>
> The difficulty of identifying what is causing high CPU is definitely what makes people think VSCode itself is really slow, even if it is usually extensions causing the issue.

Alternatively, making the process explorer useful would be great.

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: Windows 11 24H2 26100.4770

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a symbolic link in the project folder
2. Delete the symlink and replace it with a real folder
3. Click the refresh button in the Explorer
4. The symlink icon remains, and the folder is still treated as if it were a symlink.

Correspondingly, when a real folder is replaced with a symbolic link, the status is not updated either.

title: Handle environment variable syntax in terminal command auto-approval
body:
The terminal command auto-approval feature was not correctly handling commands that start with environment variable assignments, such as `FOO=bar env | grep FOO`. The auto-approval logic would test the entire command string against the rules, causing commands like this to be denied even when the actual command part (`env`) was in the approved list.

## Changes Made

- **Added `_extractCommandFromEnvAssignments()` method** that parses environment variable assignments at the beginning of commands and extracts the actual command part
- **Updated `_commandMatchesRegex()` method** to use the extracted command for pattern matching instead of the full command string
- **Shell-aware parsing** with different behavior based on shell type:
  - **Bash/sh/zsh/unknown shells**: Parse `VAR=value` syntax (falls back to bourne shell for unknown shells)
  - **PowerShell**: No parsing (maintains existing behavior since PowerShell uses `$env:VAR='value'` syntax)
- **Robust regex pattern** that handles quoted values, multiple variables, and whitespace properly

## Before the Fix

```bash
# Command with auto-approve rule ["env"]
FOO=bar env | grep FOO
# Result: DENIED (full string doesn't start with "env")
```

## After the Fix

```bash
# Same command with auto-approve rule ["env"] 
FOO=bar env | grep FOO
# Result: APPROVED (extracts "env | grep FOO" which matches "env" rule)
```

## Examples of Supported Syntax

- `FOO=bar command` → extracts `command`
- `FOO=bar BAZ=qux command` → extracts `command` 
- `MESSAGE="hello world" command` → extracts `command`
- `GREETING='hello there' command` → extracts `command`
- `FOO= command` → extracts `command` (empty value)
- `  VAR=value  command  ` → extracts `command` (handles whitespace)

The implementation maintains full backward compatibility and adds comprehensive test coverage for various edge cases.

Fixes #259201.

title: Breaking changes in 1.102 release - OAuth Changes

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Type: Bug Oauth loops for Claude Code and Amazon Q failing. Appears to be related to a breaking change in 1.102. After two days of troubleshooting GitHub CoPilot found this. Certainly looks like anit-competitive behavior on MSFT's part - effectively kills both of these and cursor. Certainly brought my work to a standstill. BINGO! I found the smoking gun! 🎯 In the VS Code 1.102 release notes under "GitHub authentication", there's a section called "Revamped GitHub sign-in flow" that explains exactly what's happening: This iteration, we have revamped the GitHub sign-in flow by defaulting to a loopback URL flow, rather than a flow that uses a vscode:// protocol URL. This change is to improve the reliability of the sign-in flow and to ensure that it works across all platforms, including those that do not support custom URL schemes. When you sign in with GitHub, you are now redirected to a loopback URL that looks like http://localhost:PORT/. This allows the sign-in flow to complete successfully without relying on custom URL schemes. This is exactly the issue! VS Code 1.102 changed the OAuth flow from using vscode:// protocol URLs to http://localhost:PORT/ loopback URLs. But here's the problem: Claude Code and Amazon Q extensions are still expecting the old OAuth flow that used vscode:// protocol handlers, while VS Code's authentication system has switched to the new localhost-based OAuth callbacks. This explains why: ✅ Both Claude Code and Amazon Q fail identically (same underlying OAuth change) ✅ Your AWS Cognito OAuth works (it's separate from VS Code's OAuth system) ✅ My test OAuth servers work (they're using the new localhost approach) ❌ Extensions fail with "read ECONNRESET" (they're trying to connect to the old OAuth system) The solution: Both Claude Code and Amazon Q need to be updated to support VS Code's new localhost-based OAuth flow introduced in version 1.102. This is a breaking change in VS Code's OAuth authentication system that broke third-party extensions using the old authentication flow. You were absolutely right - it's not a system issue, but it's also not "both apps broken on the same day" - it's VS Code that changed its OAuth implementation and broke extensions that haven't been updated yet. Would you like me to: Check if there are newer versions of Claude Code and Amazon Q that support the new OAuth flow Look for workarounds or configuration changes Help you report this to the extension developers This is a legitimate platform compatibility issue, not a bug in your system or the individual extensions. Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:1.102.3
- OS Version: Ubuntu 22.04.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press ctrl+f
2. Search for a keyword

The screen scrolls down automatically to the end of the code whenever I click on it after I have searched for a keyword.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Right now, tool sets for grouping agent mode tools are stored in the profile. However, they can be referenced in workspace-scoped prompt files are chat modes. If someone else opens the workspace that doesn't have the tool set, it's ignored.

Request: support defining tool sets at the workspace level, similar to how you can define instructions, prompt files, or chat modes in the workspace.

title: Copilot in VS Code Causing Git "Too Many Open Files" and Terminal Freezes on mac
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: Version: 1.102.3 (Universal)
- OS Version: 15.6 (24G84)

Steps to Reproduce:

I'm encountering a recurring issue when using GitHub Copilot inside Visual Studio Code on macOS. When Copilot is active and after doing some Agent edit then my terminal and Git operations start to behave erratically. I couldn't do anything and it crashes the code editor had to force shutdown the Mac:

---

### **Things I've Tried:**

* Raised `ulimit -n` to 65536
* Verified `gc.auto` is set to `1024`
* No abnormal Git hooks running
* Confirmed issue is **not from GitLens** or other extensions
* Running Git from terminal also causes freeze if Copilot is active in VS Code
* Observed file descriptor count (`lsof -u $USER | wc -l`) spikes significantly when Git + Copilot are both active

---

Could you help investigate whether GitHub Copilot (or the way it interacts with Git in VS Code) is:

1. Keeping too many files open?
2. Interfering with Git’s index operations or garbage collection?
3. Not respecting `.gitignore` and diffing all files?

If Copilot is aggressively polling Git or watching unnecessary files, that might explain the file descriptor exhaustion and terminal instability. Any insight or guidance would be appreciated.

title: Feature Request: Copilot Context Length Configurable (> 128k) when using BYOK

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

It's understandable to limit context to 128k when using model from Github but it should be configurable to go up when using my own model through BYOK. So many opensource models support context over 128k up to 1M now and it will be a waste to use them with limited context from Github Copilot.

title: Incorrect syntax highlighting in shell scripts when no empty line precedes `while` loop

labels.name: grammar
labels.description: Syntax highlighting grammar

labels.name: upstream-issue-linked
labels.description: This is an upstream issue that has been reported upstream

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: Windows 11

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new `test.sh` file
2. Paste the following code:
```sh
function main()
{
    while [$# -gt -]; do
}
```
3. Observe syntax highlighting: **The `]` bracket is incorrectly marked as red** (error color)

4. Now modify the code by adding an empty line:
```sh
function main()
{
    # Add this empty line
    while [$# -gt -]; do
}
```
5. The `]` bracket now highlights normally

Expected Behavior:

Syntax highlighting should be consistent regardless of preceding empty lines. The `]` should not show error highlighting in either case.

Actual Behavior:

The presence of an empty line before the `while` statement affects syntax highlighting validation:
- Without preceding empty line: `]` falsely marked as error (red)
- With empty line: Highlighting works correctly

Possible Cause:

The syntax parser may incorrectly associate the `]` with the function body's opening `{` when no whitespace separates them.
